docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Sharpe made millions in the insurance business, then decided to use his wealth to make the world a better place, one child at a time. Called by God, he said, he established a nondenominational Christian school for troubled children and teenagers who had passed through juvenile courts, foster care and broken homes.

headline.main: Christian School Questioned Over Discipline for Wayward

docs.abstract: Five staff members at Heartland Christian Academy, nondenominational Christian school in Newark, Mo, that uses old-time religion and old-fashioned discipline to try to save troubled children, are charged with multiple counts of felony child abuse; they are accused of taking discipline too far, ordering 11 students, ages 13 to 17, to stand in pits of cow manure as punishment for infractions such a fighting and being disrespectful to instructors; Sheriff David Parrish says workers at dairy saw students standing chest-deep in manure; dairy is owned by Charles Sharpe, millionaire businessman who founded school; he claims punishment is to shovel manure, not stand in it; says he has stopped that form of punishment because it was bad public relations, not because he considers it illegal or abusive, or health risk; notes that of 11 students removed from school by State Division of Family Services, eight have been returned to school by their parents or legal guardians; Sharpe and school and ministries he heads have filed suits charging various local government officials with harassment; photos; map (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Sect Clings to the Web In the Face of Beijing's Ban Computer-minded followers of the outlawed spiritual movement Falun Gong are using temporary cell phone numbers, encryption programs and obscure Internet services based overseas to poke holes in the Chinese government's electronic wall and keep the remaining network of followers connected. Since China set out to crush Falun Gong nearly two years ago, as many as 200 people have died, possibly thousands have been beaten or tortured and millions have been cowed into renouncing their faith. A1 Chinese officials confirmed reports that Falun Gong followers died in a labor camp, but conflicting accounts of what happened were unresolved. A10

docs.lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company wants to send Americans back to school to learn how to drive sport utility vehicles. After buying a stake in the largest chain of driving schools, Top Driver Inc., a few months ago, the automaker is developing a course to teach motorists how to drive sport utility vehicles differently from cars. Top Driver officials said the course would cover all aspects of driving, including rollover risk, the long stopping distances of sport utility vehicles and what to do if a tire blows out or suddenly loses its tread.

headline.main: Ford Wants to Send Drivers of Sport Utility Vehicles Back to School

docs.abstract: Ford Motor Co wants to send Americans back to school to learn how to drive sport utility vehicles; automaker, having bought stake in driving school chain Top Driver Inc, is developing course to teach motorists how SUV's differ from cars; course is being planned as Ford trades blame with Firestone over rollovers of Ford Explorers; diagrams on how to drive SUV's; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A state appeals court upheld a California law requiring employers to cover contraceptives in their prescription drug plans, rejecting Catholic Charities' argument that the law infringed on employers' religious freedom. Since the California law took effect last year, both the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and a federal court in Washington State have said that an employer's offering a drug plan without contraceptive coverage amounts to discrimination against women. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Victory For Contraception Law

docs.abstract: California appeals court uphold's state law requiring employers to cover contraceptives in their prescription drug plans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: David F. D'Alessandro could not believe what he was hearing. His fellow executives had just agreed to lie to the federal government. The managers had gathered to hash through a federal prosecutor's request for some company documents and quickly realized the records could be used as evidence that the company had been bribing foreign officials. But then one of them pointed out that the prosecutor had not issued a subpoena for the documents. After some discussion, the group decided to take a chance and say that the papers did not exist.

headline.main: Why Not to Stonewall in the Midst of a Scandal

docs.abstract: Interview with David F D'Alessandro, corporate chief executive, on his book portraying how companies often fail to protect long-term corporate brand image when in pursuit of short-term goals; he discusses how effort to stonewall in midst of scandal threatens brand; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What stopped the political juggernaut of the health insurance industry? For years, the industry overpowered and outwitted its critics on Capitol Hill, deploying a small army of lobbyists, health policy experts and political strategists to block legislation defining patients' rights.

headline.main: Well-Prepared Critics of Health Industry Shaped Debate on Patients' Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Insurance Department said yesterday that it had added a Spanish version to a Web site that provides information about a state program to make reduced-cost health insurance available to small-business owners and their employees, and to sole proprietors and to workers whose employers do not provide health insurance. The program, called Healthy NY, was enacted last year, and its Web site, www.healthyny.com, has until now been in English only. The site provides information about eligibility criteria and rates, which vary by county. Information can also be obtained by telephone, at (866) 432-5849. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Business Briefing | Insurance Information In Spanish

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Vice President Dick Cheney is quoted as saying he looks on his pacemaker as ''an insurance policy'' (front page, July 1). I am happy for him that he can afford ''an insurance policy,'' unlike my family.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here in the rural South, the image of AIDS today looks very much like Tyeste W. Roney. Not a gay white man. Not a crack-addicted prostitute. But a 20-year-old black woman with a gold stud in her nose, an orange bandanna covering her braids, and her nickname, Easha, tattooed on one leg.

headline.main: Epidemic Takes Toll on Black Women

docs.lead_paragraph: The patients' rights legislation that cleared the Senate last week is the product of five years of struggle to overcome intense industry opposition and brutal partisan maneuvering. But in the world of health policy, this was supposed to be the easy one. Ahead lies the more complicated -- and more costly -- challenge of providing prescription drug benefits to the 39 million elderly and disabled people in the Medicare program. And there is the even more fundamental issue of the 43 million Americans who have no health insurance.

headline.main: After Patients' Rights: Vast Needs, Higher Hurdles
